Name: Costa Rica Signature Reserve Don Pepe
Review: A nicely balanced version of the new American style of espresso: bright but not too bright, naturally sweet, citrusy but roundly and ripely so.

Name: Guatemala Waykan
Review: A classically sweet, citrusy cup with quietly intricate complications, particularly incense-toned herb and floral notes.

Name: Ecuador Cahuasqui
Review: An intriguing espresso, with a dynamic, wide-ranging intensity that probably derives in part from a mild, sweet fruit ferment. Adventurers welcome, classicists beware.
Coffee Origin: Cahuasqui region, Imbabura Province, north-central Ecuador

Name: Nicaragua Espresso del Patron
Review: A darkish medium roast develops the chocolate and caramel in this solid, accessible espresso.
Coffee Origin: Las Sabanas Municipality, Madriz Department, Nicaragua

Name: Guatemala Palo Blanco
Review: A classic espresso in the new-American, lighter-roasted style, sweet and honey-toned, softly bright.

Name: Colombia Finca Recuerdo
Review: An espresso original and provocative enough in its sweet, shifty floral and fruit notes to mildly polarize three experienced tasters. Try it and see for yourself.

Name: Guatemala La Merced
Review: Those who value a crisp dry chocolate with a floral edge should particularly enjoy this coffee, which may owe its dry chocolate and flowers to the heirloom Bourbon-variety trees that produced it.

Name: Panama Santa Teresa Natural
Review: The natural or dried-in-the-fruit processing here nets a crisp floral, anise and stone-fruit profile rather than the lusher tropical fruit profile we often associate with natural-processed coffees. If the crisp floral fruit notion sounds good to you, you may find yourself weighing in with John DiRuocco’s 95 on this one.

Name: El Salvador Lagunita Finca Los Planes Honey
Review: A bright, citrusy espresso nuanced with chocolate and a hint of lavender-like flowers.

Name: Kenya Karindundu
Review: A powerhouse, flavor-saturated, classic Kenya cup: bright, deep and juicy-sweet.

Name: Yirgacheffe Mini-Me 2016
Review: A fine Yirgacheffe paradox: Crisp, delicate yet opulently sweet.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Shoye
Review: An elegant washed Sidamo cup, both deeply sweet and delicately tart.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Panama Finca Las Brujas Geisha Natural
Review: An impeccable natural-processed Gesha: sweetly tart, complete in structure, with levitating fruit and flower notes and a seemingly infinite finish.

Name: P.r.o. Coffee Ethiopia Yirgacheffe
Review: Both balanced and deeply complex, elegant and exotic, a fine and utterly satisfying Yirgacheffe.

Name: Gichichi Peaberry Kenya
Review: A crisp, sweetly floral Kenya cup with an extra aromatic lift from delicate hints of myrrh.

Name: La Leona Colombia
Review: An invitingly complex, sweetly spice-toned Colombia cup bookended by rich notes of roasted cacao nib.

Name: P.r.o. Coffee No.11 Espresso
Review: This smooth, subtly pungent espresso nicely rides a richly fig-toned chocolate from aroma through milk.

Name: P.r.o. Coffee No. 31 Espresso
Review: An inviting espresso for those who prefer tactfully roasted, sweet-toned darker roasts. Particularly attractive in milk, which rounds the zesty orange and sweetens the roasty chocolate.

Name: P.r.o. Coffee No.3
Review: Leads with a tart brightness nicely softened by sweet floral undertones, especially in milk.

Name: Ethiopia Awassa
Review: A pretty washed-process Ethiopia coffee characterized by dried fruit and chocolate notes throughout.

Name: Las Lajas Alma Negra Full Natural
Review: Spicy-sweet flowers and fruit drive this pretty, natural-processed Costa Rica.
Coffee Origin: Sabanilla de Alajuela, Central Valley, Costa Rica

Name: Blue Sky Breakfast Blend
Review: A journey through sweet, vanilla-toned florals to zesty citrus that concludes in aromatic wood and tobacco—a wild and interesting ride.

Name: Ethiopia Kore Kochere Yirgacheffe Natural
Review: A crisp, clean, appealingly fruit-toned natural-processed Yirgacheffe cup.

Name: Blade Runner Blend
Review: A balanced, exciting, zesty-sweet and enchantingly floral espresso blend.

Name: Laura’s Reserve SL-28
Review: A stellar representation of the much-admired SL-28 coffee variety—crisp yet lush, powerful—and one of our highest-rated coffees this year.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawaii

Name: Ethiopia Limu Natural G1
Review: A powerfully aromatic, berry-toned natural-process coffee that finishes saturated with a particularly sweet, fragrant sandalwood.
Coffee Origin: Limu, Jimma Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Panama Finca Mama Cata Microlot Tona
Review: A zesty, sweet, inviting blend of coffee varieties that includes the rare and prized Gesha.
Coffee Origin: Alto Quiel, Boquete growing region, western Panama

Name: Sidamo Natural
Review: A sweetly fruit-toned, spicy-tart Ethiopia cup.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: El Salvador Laguna Las Ranas
Review: A classic El Salvador cup: gently and sweetly tart, plush, balanced, with a rich, nut-toned butterscotch sweetness.
Coffee Origin: Apaneca Municipality, Ahuachapán Department, El Salvador

Name: Kenya AA
Review: A gently aromatic coffee that sings in the bright, balanced acidity and levitating mouthfeel.

Name: Mr. David Mburu Kenya
Review: A complex Kenya with a bold, confident structure and an exotic combination of flavor notes; a particularly compelling choice for afternoon rejuvenation.

Name: Meaza Ethiopia
Review: A beautifully balanced and complete wet-processed Yirgacheffe cup, lyrical in structure and sweetly inviting from aroma to finish.
Coffee Origin: Borena Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Costa Rica Dota El Vapor
Review: A pretty, caramel-toned cup for those who like their coffees crisp and chocolaty.
Coffee Origin: Santa Maria de Dota Valley, Tarrazú growing region, Costa Rica

Name: Cafe Rivense Costa Rica El Mango
Review: Successfully roasted to a profile just a bit darker than the usual medium, netting an intense, flavor-saturated cup.

Name: Costa Rica Sonora Colorado Black Honey
Review: An appealing cup for those who like sweet florals up front and a refreshingly crisp finish.

Name: Costa Rica Sol Naciente White Honey
Review: An elegant, balanced cup with particularly compelling acidity: bright, lively, juicy. We would have rated this vivacious coffee one point higher had the cups not been slightly uneven.

Name: Costa Rica La Altura
Review: An unusual cup from an unusual variety of Arabica: gentle acidity with a particularly long, resonant finish.
Coffee Origin: San Isidro de Leon Cortez, Tarrazú growing region, Costa Rica

Name: Las Lajas Perla Negra Natural
Review: An impressive cocoa- and fruit-toned, sweetly rich cup.

Name: Costa Rica Finca Chispirta
Review: A confident, lively, sweet-toned Costa Rica cup that leads with deeply nuanced chocolate.

Name: Signature Reserve Don Pepe
Review: An original cup: spicy, sweetly tart, balanced.

Name: Costa Rica Finca La Pastora Carlos Montero Lot #1
Review: A delicate, sweet cup centered around spicy floral notes and rich, nut-toned aromatic wood: refined and understated.
Coffee Origin: San Marcos de Tarrazú, Tarrazú growing region, Costa Rica

Name: Costa Rica Alberto Guardia Bourbon Natural
Review: An elegantly rich, floral- and fruit-toned dried-in-the-fruit Costa Rica cup.

Name: Costa Rica Sumava Caturra Natural
Review: An inviting natural-processed cup, with a whisper of sweet ferment suggesting rum cordial.

Name: Costa Rica Las Cuadras F1 Hybrid Natural
Review: A paradoxical dried-in-the-fruit cup, as delicately tart as it is deeply sweet and fruit-driven.

Name: Costa Rica Los Crestones Double-Washed
Review: A classic washed-style Costa Rica cup: sweet-toned, subtle, balanced. Enjoy it with any sweet pastry accompaniment.

Name: Ninety Plus Silvia Solkiln N2
Review: Espressos, particularly single-origin espressos, don’t get much better than this one, seething with fruit, floral and incense-like nuance yet delicately balanced and complete.

Name: P.R.O. Special Blended Coffee
Review: A balanced but intricate blend, impressive in its layered, subtle complexity.

Name: P.R.O. Blended Coffee
Review: Delicate, zesty fruit and crisp lavender energize a vivacious but delicately balanced blend.
Coffee Origin: Panama; Brazil; Costa Rica; Ethiopia; Guatemala

Name: Guatemala HHT Primavera
Review: A bright and zesty espresso in the latest style, but with enough rounding chocolate, sweetness and balance to keep it accessible.

Name: Las Nubes Sudan Rume Natural
Review: A very interesting tree variety and tactful dried-in-the-fruit processing produces a subtly original and resonant espresso.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca Department, southwest Colombia

Name: Ipanema Special Reserve Pulped
Review: References a rather traditional style of espresso, dry and sweetly savory, rich with baker’s chocolate, nut and jammy fruit.
Coffee Origin: Sul de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Misty Valley Ethiopia
Review: A delicate, harmonious, berry-toned natural-processed Yirgacheffe coffee.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe Gedeb G1 Lot 118
Review: An inviting Yirgacheffe with exotic spice and floral notes grounded in rich cocoa tones.

Name: Costa Rica Alberto Guardia Venecia Natural
Review: A clean, elegant natural-processed Costa Rica cup with pretty cocoa, dried fruit and spicy floral notes.

Name: Ethiopia Kossa Kebena
Review: A fruit-driven, harmoniously balanced Ethiopia natural.
Coffee Origin: Limu Kossa District, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Myanmar Mya Za Di Natural
Review: This unusual dried-in-the-fruit coffee from an unusual origin was polarizing around the Coffee Review cupping table. One cupper felt the wood notes were none too aromatic and dominated; two others found the wood notes richly spicy and the floral notes overridingly complex and persuasive. Try it if you like the more incense-toned, spicier style of Ethiopia natural-processed coffees.
Coffee Origin: Mya Ze Di Village, Ywangan Township, Myanmar

Name: Signature Reserve Sidama 1 FTO Shilcho Red Cherry
Review: A lively, delicate coffee with appealing citrus, dried fruit and spice notes and exemplary social and environmental credentials.

Name: Bolivia Caranavi
Review: A coffee from an underdog origin that will appeal to those who prefer round, sweet nut-tones and gently brisk rather than bright acidity.
Coffee Origin: Caranavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia

Name: Kenya Karatu
Review: A compelling confluence of sweet, tart and floral notes, with a hint of umami intrigue in both the aroma and cup.

Name: Ethiopia Hambela Natural
Review: An intricate, delicately composed natural-processed Ethiopia, rife with berry and exotic aromatic wood notes.
Coffee Origin: Hambela Wamena District, Guji Zone, Oromia region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Ethiopia Gedeb Natural
Review: A natural-processed coffee without a hint of ferment, only a deep, honey-like sweetness and intricate floral and incense-like notes.

Name: Sumatra Tano Batak
Review: Extraordinary Sumatra, finely structured and utterly original in its aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Kenya Gathiruini
Review: A complex, resonant Kenya, saturated with lush flower, herb and fruit notes.

Name: Kenya Thageini
Review: A levitating Kenya cup with flawless structure and extraordinary aromatics, lushly tropical, yet elegantly pure.

Name: Kenya Gatomboya Peaberry
Review: An extraordinary Kenya, intense yet balanced and accessible.

Name: Elida Natural “Dragonfly Lot”
Review: Deep, nuanced sweetness (ripe banana, honeysuckle) and a discreet tickle of cidery ferment envelop drier notes: baker’s chocolate, lemon zest. Fine variation on the fruit-forward naturals theme.

Name: Colombia Solarte
Review: A refined, balanced, sweetly tart Colombia cup, animated by cocoa notes throughout.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca Department, southwestern Colombia

Name: El Aguila Pacamara El Salvador
Review: A complex Pacamara cup: rich, sweet and driven by deeply expressed cocoa and spicy aromatic wood.
Coffee Origin: Santa Ana growing region, El Salvador

Name: Africa Specialty Blend
Review: A vibrant and inviting citrus- and cocoa-toned blend.

Name: Worka Ethiopia
Review: A particularly elegant Yirgacheffe cup, deeply and complexly nuanced.

Name: Waykan Guatemala
Review: A pretty violet-toned Central America cup with compelling chocolate notes throughout and a hint of sweetly tart, Kenya-like blackcurrant.

Name: Worka Espresso
Review: Chocolate, citrus and florals carry this engaging, sweetly tart Yirgacheffe espresso.

Name: Hambela Natural
Review: A paradoxically juicy-crisp Ethiopia cup, both delicately sweet and bracingly crisp.
Coffee Origin: Hambela Wamena District, Guji Zone, Oromia region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Honduras Natural
Review: A chocolaty cup with sweet-fermenty, brandy-like nuance throughout.
Coffee Origin: Marcala growing region, La Paz Department, Honduras

Name: Kenya Kiamabara
Review: A sweet, spicy-crisp, floral-toned Kenya beauty.

Name: Gisuma Rwanda
Review: A crisp, sweet Rwanda cup with appealing spicy-floral intrigue.

Name: Ethiopia Zonegediyo Gedeb
Review: An intriguingly composed Ethiopia cup, with walnut notes enveloping spicy florals and sweet cocoa.
Coffee Origin: Gedeb District, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Costa Rica Tarrazu
Review: A crisp, sweetly nut-toned cup with inviting caramel notes and hints of sweet flowers.
Coffee Origin: Santa Maria de Dota valley, Tarrazu growing region, Costa Rica

Name: Indonesia Sumatra Tano Batak
Review: A classic Sumatra, earth-inflected yet pure, rich with tobacco and incense notes balanced by delicate citrus, floral, and cocoa.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Mexico Cañada Fria
Review: An attractive Mexico coffee with fine floral top notes and chocolate and aromatic wood undertones.

Name: Selian Tanzania
Review: An intriguing coffee with its spicily crisp composure and sweetly drying nut tones.
Coffee Origin: Arusha growing region, Mt. Meru, Tanzania

Name: Yemen Rayyan Mill
Review: A hint of sweet ferment complicates this light-roasted, delicately berry- and herb-toned cup from the historic origin of Yemen.
Coffee Origin: Haraz (also Haraaz) growing region, north-central Yemen

Name: El Salvador Finca Loma La Gloria
Review: A delicately high-toned, sweetly crisp El Salvador cup, classic and breakfasty.
Coffee Origin: El Boqueron, Volcan de San Salvador, El Salvador

Name: Guatemala San Antonio El Bosque
Review: Delicate but subtly strong-charactered Guatemala; the sweet walnut juxtaposed with tart fruit is unusual and appealing.

Name: Tolima Colombia
Review: An especially savory coffee driven by aromatic wood notes with a whisper of cherry blossoms.

Name: El Vapor Espresso
Review: A bright, crisp, balanced Costa Rica espresso, impressive both as straight shot and in milk.
Coffee Origin: Santa Maria de Dota valley, Tarrazu growing region, Costa Rica

Name: Ethiopia Konga Kebele
Review: A pretty Yirgacheffe cup that is simultaneously crisp and lush, floral and chocolaty.

Name: Costa Rica El Vapor
Review: An exceptionally crisp, delicately tart cup enveloped in notes of sweet florals.
Coffee Origin: Santa Maria de Dota valley, Tarrazu growing region, Costa Rica

Name: Colombia Las Margaritas Sudan Rume
Review: An elegant, berry-toned, chocolaty version of the rare coffee variety Sudan Rume.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia

Name: Alma Vieja 10-Year Anniversary Blend
Review: Balanced, complete, with a subtle, deeply layered complexity. A versatile cup, quietly vibrant as a black coffee but authoritative with whitener.

Name: Costa Rica El Aguacate White Honey
Review: A tartly sweet, crisp honey-processed cup with exotic floral undertones.

Name: El Salvador Finca El Pozo Microlot Honey
Review: The honey reference in the processing method is a literal experience in this El Salvador cup, enveloping and promoting the pleasing balance of sweet and tart sensations.
Coffee Origin: Ataco, Apaneca-Ilamatepec, Ahuachapán Department, El Salvador

Name: Coko Rwanda Honey
Review: Crisply bright sweet-tart floral tones animate the cup from aroma through finish.

Name: Costa Rica La Frente Cerro Verde Black Honey Microlot
Review: Among the few black-honey-processed coffees we see in any given year, this Costa Rica stands out for its delicate but rich, spice-inflected sweetness.

Name: Costa Rica Esnider Rodriguez Red Honey
Review: A crisply rich, richly nut-toned honey cup, complicated by elegant floral notes.

Name: El Salvador Anny Ruth’s Red Honey Loma La Loria
Review: A solid, satisfying cup, cedary and deep.

Name: Brazil Espirito Santo Pulped Natural
Review: With a savory edge reminiscent of a fine Kenya, this coffee is crisply high-toned yet also deeply sweet.
Coffee Origin: Montanhas do Espirito Santo growing region, Espirito Santo State, Brazil

Name: Thailand Java Semi-Washed
Review: Chocolate all the way through, complicated by rich spice notes and pungent florals.

Name: Honduras Finca Las Flores Honey
Review: An inviting honey-processed cup with a hint of sweet brandy-toned ferment lifted by sweet florals and tart fruit notes.
Coffee Origin: Marcala growing region, La Paz Department, Honduras

Name: Sol Naciente Costa Rica Red Honey
Review: This pretty Costa Rica cup would be a perfect match for a lemon tart: sweet and crisp, with rounding notes of cacao nib and delicate flowers.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Chinga Peaberry
Review: A delicately expressive version of the Kenya paradox, savory yet sweetly floral, gently zesty.

Name: Ethiopia Hambela Washed
Review: A washed Ethiopia cup both delicate and resonant, orchestral in its aromatic complexity.
Coffee Origin: Hambela Wamena District, Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Milepost Kenya Nyeri Kiamabara
Review: A fine rendition of the classic Kenya cup—sweetly tart, juicy and spice-inflected.

Name: Ethiopia Hambela Natural
Review: An elegant natural-processed Ethiopia with a hint of pleasing sweet, cocoa-toned ferment (think rum cordial).
Coffee Origin: Hambela District, Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Kenya Muranga Gondo AA
Review: A powerhouse Kenya cup with tart-savory depth infused with sweet cocoa and spice tones.

Name: Kenya Small-Lot Reserve Karatina AA
Review: Grand, complete Kenya: sweetly savory, lushly dry, flower-laced, singular.

Name: Washed Yirgacheffe Aramo Alemayehu Berhanu
Review: A spectacular wet-processed Yirgacheffe with the deep, savory intrigue of umami saturating sweet floral and spice tones.

Name: Natural Yirgacheffe Konga G1
Review: A crisp, delicately floral natural Yirgacheffe bookended by spice and aromatic wood notes.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Gathugu
Review: A Kenya for those who value subtle power and layered complexity.

Name: Ethiopia Hambela Nomad
Review: A classic wet-processed Ethiopia: crisp, brisk, yet lyrically sweet and floral.
Coffee Origin: Hambela Wamena District, Guji Zone, Oromia Region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Kenya Nyeri Mahiga
Review: Classic Kenya; sweet but seriously dry, berry-toned, elegant.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Ichamama
Review: Delicate yet strongly stated version of the Kenya paradox: dry yet juicy, tart yet sweet, subtly savory.

Name: SFCC House Blend Espresso Capsule
Review: A crisp, gentle espresso with Fair Trade credentials and a value price point for Nespresso owners.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Chelelektu
Review: A pretty natural Yirgacheffe, made even more enticing by a hint of cinnamon spice in both the nose and cup.

Name: Ethiopia Papilio Sidamo
Review: Aromatic wood and spice notes turn this fruit- and flower-driven Sidamo crisp and gently bracing.

Name: Kenya AB Civet
Review: Worth trying for its unusual processing method alone, this Kenya civet coffee is also exceedingly delicate, closer to drinking a tart herbal tea than a traditional Kenya coffee.

Name: Colombia “Amerika Kusini”
Review: Impressive sweetness and quiet complexity in a briskly balanced, straightforward Colombia.

Name: Passport Collection Kenya Ichamara
Review: The usual paradox of great Kenyas is embodied here by a chocolaty sweetness working against a lively, juniper-like pungency, though the usual tart berry and subtle flowers contribute too. An exceptional and original Kenya.

Name: Ethiopia Limu Natural No. 701
Review: A voluptuary’s cup, lavish with layered fruit, flower and fragrant wood notes.

Name: Costa Rica La Falda Grande
Review: Quietly original Costa Rica: subtle fruit deepened and complicated by a crisp, savory edge led by clove and pine.

Name: Rwanda Fair Trade Dukundekawa Musasa
Review: A slightly darkish roast quiets acidity and deepens a zesty, sweet-savory Rwanda.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Aricha
Review: A delicate, berry-driven natural-process Ethiopia with rounding cocoa and nut influences.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe YCFCU Idido
Review: An elegant, cleanly-stated Yirgacheffe: crisp, sweet, delicately complex.

Name: Ardent Espresso Blend
Review: A sweet-toned, fudgy espresso blend whose supporting fruit and floral tones especially sing in milk.

Name: Aurora Espresso Blend
Review: A proudly chocolaty espresso both straight up and in milk, enlivened by sweetly tart orange zest.

Name: Amiable Espresso Blend
Review: A pleasingly straightforward, accessible, balanced espresso blend.

Name: Indonesia Wahana Estate Natural
Review: A lushly sweet, natural-process Sumatra with a discreet hint of sweet ferment and a long, crisply drying finish.
Coffee Origin: Sidikalang, Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Indonesia Sumatra “Blue Bianca” Dolok Sanggul
Review: Inviting earthy, wet fallen-leaf notes combined with tropical fruit and deep chocolate suggestions generate a classic wet-hulled Sumatra cup.
Coffee Origin: Dolok Sanggul, Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Meriah Aceh King Batak
Review: Quiet oppositions: A sweet floral character pleasantly overlays a ground of tobacco and nut.
Coffee Origin: Gayo (also Aceh) growing region, Aceh Province, northern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Lintong Blue Batak
Review: A deep-toned, complexly expressive Sumatra in which an unusual but inviting spice note emerges, suggesting cumin in its sweetly drying richness.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia

Name: Batak Nauli Sumatra
Review: A coffee that crescendos, like a deep breath, into a round, tropical, earthy sweetness.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia

Name: Sumatra Gayo “Adsenia” Triple Pick
Review: A multi-layered Sumatra wet-hulled profile that opens with pretty floral notes and settles into a crisp, balanced, chocolaty cup with a roundly sweet finish.
Coffee Origin: Gayo (also Aceh) growing region, Aceh Province, northern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Sumatra King Batak Washed
Review: An unusual Sumatra in that it was conventionally wet-processed rather than processed by the more typical Sumatra wet-hulled method. For this reason, perhaps, it is a delicate cup, yet richly so, with hints of the tobacco suggestions characteristic of traditionally wet-hulled Sumatras.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia

Name: King Batak Honey
Review: A honey-processed Sumatra, crisper and zestier perhaps than the more traditional wet-hulled Sumatra, with a pleasing balance of complexly expressed fruit and savory carob and fresh fir.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northwestern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Sumatra Black Panther
Review: Earthy tobacco, pungent fruit, sweetly heady flowers, an impressive example of the finest wet-hulled Sumatra profile.
Coffee Origin: Pondok, Aceh Province, northern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Sumatra Lintong Mutu Batak
Review: Intricate layering of pungent citrus, sweet flowers, moist tobacco and aromatic wood, an original yet deeply characteristic expression of the best style of traditional wet-hulled Sumatras.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia

Name: Batak Nuali Sumatra
Review: A coconut-toned, citrusy coffee with a savory character complicated by mango and chocolate suggestions.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia

Name: Lake Street Espresso Blend
Review: A very pretty, balanced espresso blend that runs through all the notes: sweet-tart, chocolaty, nutty, floral.

Name: Amaro Gayo Natural Ethiopia
Review: A complex and dazzling rendition of the dried-in-the-fruit Sidamo cup: fruit-forward with floral, aromatic wood, citrus and chocolate intrigue.
Coffee Origin: Amaro Mountains, Sidama (also Sidamo) growing area, southern Ethiopia

Name: Brazil Fazenda Alta Vista
Review: An exceptional Brazil natural: a nuanced and harmonious convergence of sweet, tart and nut.
Coffee Origin: Christina, Mantiqueira, Minas Gerais State, southeastern Brazil

Name: El Tontolo Manguito Honduras
Review: A rich, crisp, deeply sweet coffee with a chocolate throughline.

Name: Mount Ali Taiwan Typica Natural
Review: An intriguing cup for U.S. coffee-drinkers, both in regard to its origin and its delicate, fruity-floral cup with an attractive balsamic hint.

Name: Ardi Ethiopia Natural
Review: An impressive, delicately composed but boldly aromatic natural-processed Ethiopia. Exotic but pure.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Deri Kochoha Espresso
Review: Opulent, invitingly complex, forthright as both straight shot and in cappuccino-scaled milk.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Camilina Geisha Auromar Natural
Review: A deeply engaging, complex yet balanced coffee with an impressive combination of finesse and power.
Coffee Origin: Piedra Candela, Chiriqui Province, far western Panama

Name: ManLao River Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Dry Process Gedeb Asasa
Review: A crisp but mouth-filling, fruit-forward natural-process Ethiopia with rich, round butterscotch tones.
Coffee Origin: Gedeb District, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Alma Estate Panama Natural
Review: A pretty cup from the respected Catuai variety of Arabica:chocolaty and floral, with a discreet, rogue hint of rum-toned sweet ferment.
Coffee Origin: Piedra Candela, Chiriqui Province, far western Panama

Name: Deri Kochoha Ethiopia
Review: A coffee in which opposites are at play and in balance: sweet and tart, spicy and chocolaty.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Tolima Colombia
Review: A unique cup. Suggests a good IPA: sweet, though with a citrusy hop-like character from aroma to finish.

Name: D15 The Convivio Espresso
Review: Deep, pungent but well-composed espresso that should perform particularly well in both short and long milk drinks.
Coffee Origin: Brazil; Ethiopia; Indonesia; Guatemala; Costa Rica

Name: D33 The Divine Comedy
Review: A gently roasty espresso with floral-toned apricot notes softening a crisply dry chocolate.
Coffee Origin: Brazil; Guatemala; Colombia; Indonesia; Costa Rica

Name: Cachajinas Guatemala Huehuetenango
Review: A fine Guatemala cup: elegant, exotic, delicately but confidently composed.

Name: Milepost Colombia Primaveral
Review: A compellingly enigmatic cup: both sweet and savory, spicy and tart, all in harmonious balance.

Name: Milepost Colombia Los Naranjos
Review: An inviting coffee, with fruit notes reminiscent of a mango lassi, both sweet and tart, with rounding influences of macadamia nut and gentle floral tones.

Name: Sumatra Meriah
Review: A superior variation on the pleasures associated with Sumatra coffees, including an intriguing smoke note enveloped in tropical fruit.
Coffee Origin: Aceh growing region, northwestern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: Colombia Miranda
Review: A solid cup nicely balanced between sweet flowers and tart fruit supported by a deeply expressed chocolate.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca Department, southwest Colombia

Name: San Ysidro Costa Rica
Review: A flavor-saturated, floral-toned cup enveloped by crisp aromatic wood notes.

Name: Tanzania Masangula AB
Review: An appealing coffee for those who enjoy delicate sweetness checked by the crisp zestiness of citrus and stone fruit.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Chire
Review: Both sweet and earthy, this is a coffee for lovers of unambiguous fruit flavors framed by suggestions of cask-toned Port wine.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Goro
Review: An invitingly sweet, intricate Yirgacheffe cup with a floral backbone supported by dark chocolate and spearmint suggestions.

Name: Kamwangi Factory Kenya Kirinyaga
Review: Will please those who enjoy the briskly bright, pungent fruit of a classic Kenya.

Name: Kenya Gondo
Review: An attractively austere Kenya cup poised between the crispness of citrus and stone fruit and the plush spice of aromatic wood and tea rose.

Name: Hernando Chantre Colombia
Review: A brisk, lively coffee with a liftoff from citrus and black-currant notes.

Name: El Obraje Geisha
Review: A nuanced, sweetly-tart Geisha with a confident structure and bold fruit- and flower-driven aromatics.

Name: Colombia Nariño Fiesta Natural
Review: A complex, deeply sweet coffee, nut- and fruit-toned.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Reko
Review: An exquisite washed Ethiopia with power, finesse and nuanced complexity: deeply sweet, lushly floral, elegantly spice-toned.
Coffee Origin: Kochere, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Costa Rica Alberto Guardia Bourbon Natural
Review: An unorthodox coffee with great breadth and complexity of aroma and flavor: fruit, spice, flowers, herb. Not a purist’s coffee, but big, deep and expressive. Aficionados: Think Pacamara.

Name: Uganda Kayurumba
Review: A sweetly roast-toned coffee with crisp fruit notes and an intimation of flowers.

Name: Manlao River Man Wanshan Microlot
Review: Both crisp and floral, appealing to those who enjoy dried fruit and nut notes juxtaposed with sweet flowers.

Name: Tony’s Trek
Review: An impressive coffee for a worthy cause — a deeply sweet, crisply pungent blend.

Name: Rwanda Gisuma
Review: A fine variation on a Central Africa theme: deeply sweet, richly floral, accented by chocolate and citrus.

Name: Panama Camiseta Estate
Review: A pretty Panama cup that strikes a balance between delicate sweetness and crisp spice.

Name: Colombia Finca San Jose
Review: A big Colombia that offers equal parts sweet and savory pleasure, enlivened throughout with nut and chocolate suggestions.
Coffee Origin: Pitalito, San Agustin growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia

Name: Reserve Ethiopia Halo Bariti Coop
Review: Cedar and roasted cacao nib envelope this fruit-forward, zesty cup.

Name: O’Rey Espresso Capsules
Review: A light, lean, accessible capsule espresso.

Name: Colombia San Adolfo
Review: A quietly extravagant coffee: Subtle yet rich, balanced, sweet and spice-toned; an excellent value as well.
Coffee Origin: San Adolfo, Acevedo, Huila Department, Colombia

Name: Ecuador Rancho Tio Emilio
Review: A dynamically rich cup: sweet citrus framed in spice.
Coffee Origin: La Perla, Nanegal, Pichincha growing region, northern Ecuador

Name: Laura’s Reserve SL-28
Review: The elegantly lush yet crisply pungent paradox of the SL-28 profile is expressed here with a particularly juicy, layered balance.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawaii

Name: Colombia Gabriel Munoz Samboni
Review: A balanced, spicy-floral coffee with cocoa tones throughout.

Name: Colombia Mary Cielo Salazar Soto
Review: A sweet, spice-toned, floral-edged Colombia cup.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Deri Kochoha WP
Review: An unusual Sidamo cup that offers fascinating individual notes (strawberry, roasted mint) enveloped by a dark chocolate throughline.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Validation Espresso Blend
Review: A pretty, sweetly nut- and floral-toned espresso with pleasing layered complexity and chocolate suggestions throughout, not to mention an excellent value.

Name: Brazil Fazenda Passeio Natural
Review: Juicy, exotic, port-like, and an excellent value.
Coffee Origin: Carmo de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Brazil Estancia Telese
Review: A huge floral and fruit-toned beauty: balanced and deeply sweet.
Coffee Origin: Mantiqueira de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Fazenda Sertão Brazil
Review: A crisp, sweetly spicy and nut-toned cup.
Coffee Origin: Carmo de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Fazenda Aurea South Minas Brazil
Review: Fragrant aromatic wood, fruit and flowers dominate in this pretty, crisp, deeply sweet Brazil natural.
Coffee Origin: Cerrado Miniero, Serra do Salitre growing region, Minas Gerais State

Name: Brazil Fazenda Do Serrado
Review: A sweetly spice-driven coffee with the inviting richness of fresh leather notes.
Coffee Origin: Carmo de Minas growing region, northeastern Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Carmo de Minas Canaan Estate Natural Pedreira Microlot
Review: A layered Brazil cup with a Kenya-like pungency and gentle resonance.
Coffee Origin: Carmo de Minas growing region, northeastern Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Carmo de Minas Oliveira Fernando Manoel de Oliveira Brazil Natural
Review: A stone-fruit- and citrus-framed coffee with subtle floral and nut tones.
Coffee Origin: Mantiqueira de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Boa Vista Brazil
Review: A profoundly sweet cup (lychee, honeysuckle) with supporting nut and aromatic wood nuance.
Coffee Origin: Mantiqueira de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Brazil Fazenda Beneficio Presente do Sol
Review: A sweetly intricate and pungently floral cup enveloped by chocolate tones.
Coffee Origin: Mantiqueira de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Milepost Zimbabwe AA Smaldeel Estate
Review: An unusual coffee both in structure and flavor that will appeal to those who value bold herb notes with sweet nut and spice undertones.

Name: Ethiopia Harfusa
Review: An invitingly paradoxical Yirgacheffe that integrates savory richness with delicate apple and citrus notes.

Name: Breakfast Blend (K-Cup)
Review: An accessible morning blend that will appeal to those who enjoy delicate, sweetly nut-toned coffees.

Name: Finca Buenos Aires Colombia
Review: Simultaneously delicate yet rich, with a pleasing cocoa-toned spice.

Name: Papua New Guinea Korona
Review: A crisply sweet coffee driven by stone fruit and bright herb notes.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Gatugi AA
Review: An exotically appealing Kenya, with citrus and spicy floral notes that go long and an assertive juicy-tart structure.

Name: FTO Congo SOPACDI Coop
Review: An intriguing coffee with an usual combination of floral and savory suggestions.
Coffee Origin: Kalehe, South Kivu Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo

Name: Burundi Bwayi
Review: A compelling example of a central Africa coffee, with a balance of sweet and savory elements and a pretty florality in the background throughout.

Name: Panama La Esmeralda Bosque Geisha
Review: An exceptional coffee that offers nuance, depth and layered complexity in an exhilarating version of the great Gesha profile.
